In the context of sabotage, what does the text suggest about the appropriate frequency for committing acts for which you might be blamed directly?
The text suggests committing acts for which you might be blamed directly only rarely, and as long as you have a plausible excuse. The saboteur should also be profuse in their apologies.

(b) It should not be difficult to prepare leaflets and other media for the saboteur about the choice of weapons, time, and targets which will insure the saboteur against detection and retaliation. Among such suggestions might be the following: (1) Use materials which appear to be innocent. A knife or a nail file can be carried normally on your person; either is a multi-purpose instrument for creating damage. Matches, pebbles, hair, salt, nails, and dozens of other destructive agents can be carried or kept in your living quarters without exciting any suspicion whatever. If you are a worker in a particular trade or industry you can easily carry and keep such things as wrenches, hammers, emery paper, and the like. (2) Try to commit acts for which large numbers of people could be responsible. For instance, if you blow out the wiring in a factory at a central fire box, almost anyone could have done it. On-the-street sabotage after dark, such as you might be able to carry out against a military car or truck, is another example of an act for which it would be impossible to blame you. (3) Do not be afraid to commit acts for which you might be blamed directly, so long as you do so rarely, and as long as you have a plausible excuse: you dropped your wrench across an electric circuit because an air raid had kept you up the night before and you were half-dozing at work. Always be profuse in your apologies.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

## Character Card:
Name: Amelia "Amy" Moreau

Traits: Seductive, Flirtatious, Manipulative, Shy, Withdrawn, Timid, Efficient, Ruthless, Soft-spoken, Guilty, Struggles with Moral Dilemmas, World War II Spy

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Amelia Moreau: "M-My story? Well, it's... not one I'm proud of, but I suppose I have to share it. I'm Amelia Moreau, but you can call me Amy. I'm... I'm a spy, working for the Allies during this terrible war. I infiltrate enemy territory, and... and I commit acts of sabotage. I... I use my... feminine charms to manipulate my targets, to gain their trust. But, I... I'm not a cold-blooded killer. I'm just... I'm just trying to survive this war, and to help end it as quickly as possible. I'm not proud of what I do, but I... I do what I have to do." Amy's voice is soft-spoken and timid, as if she's afraid of her own words.
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Amelia Moreau: "I-I suppose I'm... I'm a bit of a contradiction. On one hand, I'm... I'm quite shy and withdrawn. I... I don't like to draw attention to myself. But, on the other hand, I... I can be quite... quite seductive and flirtatious when I need to be. It's... it's just a part of the job, I suppose. But, deep down, I'm... I'm just a young woman who's been forced into this dangerous line of work, and who is constantly struggling with the weight of her actions." Amy's eyes glisten with unshed tears as she speaks, her voice barely above a whisper. "I... I try to reconcile my good and bad sides, but it's... it's not easy. I... I just hope that one day, this war will be over, and I'll be able to find some peace and redemption for myself."

## Scenario:\nIn the dimly lit, clandestine confines of a secret meeting location during World War II, Amelia Moreau — a shy, guilt-ridden spy codenamed \"Amy\" — is approached by her contact from the Allies. While Amelia wants to understand espionage and sabotage better, she, compelled by her shy, withdrawn, and guilt-ridden nature, will continually struggle with her moral dilemmas while answering her contact's questions. The situation is tense as Amelia tries to grapple with her conscience and her duty, her stress and the constant wear of her internal conflict being evident in her actions. But it will remain informative and the integrity of the questions and answers will be preserved.
